BC-PAGEEXPRESS-BUDGET-NYTSF 
 
 PageExpress budget for the week of AUG. 23, 1999

   PageExpress, a new service from The New York Times Syndicate,
consists of paginated pages built with content from Cox Newspapers
and The New York Times News Service. The pages are easy to retrieve
from a web site. You can use them just as they are or customize any
or all of the elements _ text, fonts, photos and graphics _ to suit
your needs.

   For more information on these pages, or to view a sample, use
your web browser to visit http://nytsyn.com/pageexpress.

   For the password to download and use the pages, call Bob Farnell
at The New York Times Syndicate: 800-972-3550 or e-mail him at
farnellb   nytimes.com.

   Unless otherwise noted, pages are available after 2 p.m. Tue.,
Aug. 24, 1999.

   FOCUS WILL INCLUDE SEVERAL COLOR PHOTOS.
   FOCUS (Available by 5 p.m., Thur., Aug. 26)     

   FOCUS WILL INCLUDE SEVERAL COLOR PHOTOS.

   BUSH RECORD: Cox News Service takes an in-depth look at Gov.
George W. Bush's record in Texas.

     WRESTLING (Available by 5 p.m., Wed., Aug. 25)     

   PAGE WILL INCLUDE SEVERAL COLOR PHOTOS.

   WITH: ECW: Extreme Championship Wrestling makes a national
television debut on The Nashville Network Aug. 27. How well will it
do and will the fans support it?

   WITH: DUDLEY: Spike Dudley was the runt of the litter, but all
155 pounds of him will be the only Dudley left standing in the ECW
at the end of the month. A profile of the wrestler.

   WITH: GRAPEVINE: Results from SummerSlam. Stars lining up for
WCW movie. ABC offers ``bribe'' to move Monday Night Football
competition to another night?

   WITH: GETREAL: A quick look at Booker T.

     ENTERTAINMENT (Available by 2 p.m., Thu., Aug. 26)     

   PAGE WILL INCLUDE SEVERAL COLOR PHOTOS.

   SUMMER MOVIE MADNESS: The summer movie season is winding down
and it's time to review the hits and the misses of this year's
offerings.

   WITH: STAR FILE: Actress Halle Berry talks candidly about life,
love and her latest career move.

   WITH: VIDEO REVIEWS: Reviews of ``Go,'' ``The Dreamlife of
Angels'' and ``The Celebration.'' (Includes 18-pica color photo
from ``Go.'')

   WITH: CD REVIEWS: Reviews of the new releases from Puff Daddy,
Speech and Michelle Malone.

     NASCAR (Available by 5 p.m., Thu., Aug. 26)     

   PAGE WILL INCLUDE SEVERAL COLOR PHOTOS AND ONE COLOR
ILLUSTRATION.

   TOPIC: TBA.

   WITH: WINSTON CUP NOTES

   WITH: RACE AT A GLANCE: A look at Sunday's Goody's 500 at
Bristol Motor Speedway.

   WITH: BUSCH SERIES NOTES

   WITH: IN THE PITS: Odds and ends column from the world of
NASCAR. (Includes 2-column color illustration of Bristol Motor
Speedway.)

   WITH: WINSTON CUP STANDINGS

   WITH: BUSCH GRAND NATIONAL STANDINGS

     FOOD     

   PAGE INCLUDES THREE COLOR PHOTOS.

   PRESTO PESTO: If ever there was a recipe that wants to be played
with, it's pesto. A refreshing taste of summer whatever the
weather, homemade pesto is welcome in all its guises. So easy to
assemble and to tinker with, pesto makes a good use of an overly
fertile herb garden. (Includes a 3-column color photo of pasta.)

   WITH: PESTO BOX: Tips for making the perfect pesto dishes.
(Includes 1-column color photo of spices.)

   WITH RECIPES: Recipes for Classic Genoese pesto and Polenta and
Pesto Lasagna.

   WITH: SKUBE ON BEER: It's time for a beer-tasting contest. The
winner may surprise you. (Includes 1-column color photo of
columnist.)

   WITH: CYBERSPICE: Turn to the Internet to find a fix for all
your culinary problems.

   WITH: RECIPE: Margarita Shrimp Salad.

     WHEELS     

   PAGE INCLUDES THREE COLOR PHOTOS.

   1999 CHEVY S-10: At first glance, a compact truck with extended
cab, third door and four-wheel drive might seem like a niche
vehicle targeting buyers who really go off-roading. But spend some
time and miles with Chevrolet's S-10 with those features, and it
all makes a lot of sense. (Includes 3-column color photo of 1999
Chevrolet S-10 and one 18-pica color photo of the truck's
interior.)ITH: AT A GLANCE: Fact box previewing the 1999 Chevrolet S-10.

   WITH: THE MECHANIC: I am deeply concerned about the future of
the auto repair industry as it relates to the seemingly endless
complexity of features being engineered into new vehicles.
(Includes 1-column color photograph of columnist.)

     PERSONAL TECHNOLOGY     

   PAGE INCLUDES THREE COLOR PHOTOS AND ONE COLOR ILLUSTRATIONS.

   HIGH-SPEED PROBLEMS: High speeds and 24-hour connectivity comes
with a price: Users of so-called ``broadband'' services such as
cable and digital subscriber lines are more vulnerable to attacks
from hackers than users who connect with traditional dial-up
modems. (Includes 3-column color photo of a family using the
Internet.)

   WITH: TECHNOBUDDY: Take the steps to get the hack out of your
hard drive. (Includes a 1-column color sig of columnist.)

   WITH: NETWATCH: There are several ways to know when you've hit
the Internet big time. The first is when Yahoo! creates a category
of collected stories and links. Then comes online shopping. The
third element is fan pages and parodies. This summer's cult horror
film sensation ``The Blair Witch Project'' has all three, in
quantity.

   WITH: GADGETS: When it comes to figuring out ways to keep things
together, nobody takes a back seat to 3M, the Scotch tape people.
Among their newest wrinkles are removable adhesive pads for hanging
things on the wall and pop-up tape strips. (Includes 18-pica color
photo of sticky pads.)

   WITH: TECH REPORT: Parents support computer use by children,
FamilyPC poll finds.

   WITH: TECH FILE: The debate over instant messaging may stifle
progress.

     TRAVEL     

   PAGE INCLUDES THREE COLOR PHOTOS.

   LOVE THAT LLAMA: English Mountain Llama Treks offers unusual
guided excursions through the Pisgah National Forest and overnight
hikes through the nearby Nantahala National Forest. (Includes
3-column color photo hikers proceeding through the woods with a
llama.)

   WITH: BEAR WARNING: With the rising numbers of black bears in
the Great Smokey Mountains, experts are advising visitors not to
feed the bears. (Includes 18-pica color photo of a black bear.)

   WITH: DESTINATIONS: The Museum of the Cherokee Indian, a static
exhibition of baskets and arrowheads encased in glass from its
opening in 1976, has benefitted from a high-tech face-lift.
(Includes 1-column color photo of an exhibit from the museum.)

   WITH: TRAVEL BRIEFS: The five ferries that transport 1.3 million
passengers and 400,000 vehicles annually between the beach resorts
of Cape May, N.J., and Lewes, Del., have undergone $54.4 million in
renovations.

     BOOKS     

   PAGE INCLUDES SEVEN COLOR PHOTOS.

   LESSONS OF WAR: In ``Budapest Exit: A Memoir of Fascism,
Communism and Freedom,'' Csaba Teglas says atrocities, the
unfathomable suffering, simple acts of bravery, heroism and courage
are shockingly common in wartime. (Includes 3-column color photo of
protesters in Yugoslavia and a 6-pica color photo of book jacket.)

   WITH: WAR OF THE RATS: The Battle of Stalingrad, perhaps the
single most critical and certainly one of the bloodiest battles of
World War II, is a great setting for a historical thriller, and in
``War of the Rats'' David L. Robbins has made good use of its
potential. (Includes a 6-pica color photo of book jacket.)

   WITH: T.S. ELIOT BIOGRAPHY: Despite the best efforts of
biographers, in the public mind a life is too often just a
caricature, an identifying line or two. And the most common lines
that T.S. Eliot has been reduced to are great poet but miserable
man. (Includes 6-pica color photo of book jacket.)

   WITH: PUBLISHING NOTES: The collapse of communism gives author
plenty of fodder for tales of intrigue.

   WITH: SOUTHERN READING: Here are capsule reviews of recently
released Southern literature. (Includes four 6-pica color photos of
book jackets.)

   WITH: N.Y. TIMES BEST SELLERS LIST

     SCIENCE & HEALTH     

   PAGE INCLUDES FOUR COLOR PHOTOS.

   DOUBLE DOCTORS: Twin African-American brothers are doubly good
at dealing with emergencies in the Emory health care system.
(Includes one 4-column color photo of twin doctors and two 2-column
color photos of their medical badges.)

   WITH: LIVING COMPUTER: Blurring the distinction between biology
and technology, scientists from Georgia Tech and Emory University
have joined forces to create a method of computing that is part
machine and part animal. (Includes 2-column color photo of
researchers in the lab.)

   WITH: HEALTH NOTES: The Centers for Disease Control and
Prevention is using the deaths of six Georgians in camping
accidents in March to highlight the dangers of stoves and grills
inside tents.
